   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 6349**] is a 55 yo male with DM 2, HTN, CAD s/p IMI and DES to
   RCAx3 transferred from OSH for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, AMS,
   and ARF.
   # Sepsis: In setting of high grade bacteremia. Patient transiently on
   levophed overnight. Also received volume rescucitation with 4.5 L IVF.
   - Wean pressors, goal MAP>65
   - Monitor UOP, goal UOP>30 cc/hr. Bolus as needed
   - Continue vanco and pip/tazo, d/c ceftriaxone
   - Trend WBC and fever curve
   - Can check SvO2
   # ID: Patient with high grade bacteremia (4/4 bottles with GPCs) and
   report of wound culture with S.aureus with sensitivities unknown.
   Given that no other source identified, source may be diabetic foot
   ulcer/osteo. No CVL access in terms of line infections.  Would also
   need to consider endocarditis as source of infection.  Meningitis also
   considered given AMS, although LP deferred given difficulty with
   sedation.
   - Continue vancomycin, pip/tazo.
   - Low suspicion for meningitis, as patient was already hospitalized for
   4 days and a nosocomial meningitis is unlikely. Defer LP for now and
   hold CNS dosed ceftriaxone.
   - Surface echocardiogram today
   - Follow-up final foot plain film read
   - Trend WBC and fever
   - Consult podiatry
   # Neuro: CTH overnight negative for acute intracranial process. Likely
   multifactorial given high grade sepsis/bacteremia, ARF, and excessive
   narcotic use.
   - As above, continue vanco and pip/tazo
   - Defer LP and d/c ceftriaxone as suspicion for meningitis low
   - Follow-up neuro recs if any
   - Serial neuro exams
   - Appreciate neuron recs, EEG today
   # ARF: Creatinine trending up to 4.8 from 1.3 at OSH. Differential
   includes contrast induced nephropathy, pre-renal, AIN in setting of
   antibiotic therapy, and ATN given sepsis.  FeNa 1.1 with negative urine
   eos. Patient continues to be oliguric/anuric with 4.5L IVF challenge
   overnight.
   - Renal U/S
   - Trend UOP and creatinine
   - Renal c/s
   - Obtain [**Hospital1 49**] path records.
   - Minotr UOP
   # Respiratory Failure: Patient intubated given AMS and ?seizure for
   airway protection.  P/F <200, although patient does not have classic
   bilateral infiltrates. He also has a history of CAD, and in setting of
   volume challenge may have element of heart failure, making ARDS
   clinical diagnosis unclear.
   - [**Name2 (NI) **] volume ARDS settings for now.
   - Daily RSBI and SBT if appropriate
   - Head of the bed elevated
   - H2 blocker while intubated
   - VAP bundle
   # Ileus: Demonstrated on OSH imaging. KUB wetread with distended
   transverse colon of 12 cm.  Most likely etiology is excessive narcotic
   use as patient was on high doses of MS Contin as an outpatient and
   continued to take narcotics at the OSH.
   - PO Naloxone
   - OGT to low-intermitent suction
   - NPO
   - Hold narcotics
   - Upload OSH imaging and review with radiology.
   - Repeat KUB, if transverse colon >10 cm, consult general surgery.
   # DM: Patient likely to have elevated FS while with infection.
   - Insulin gtt
   .
   # CAD s/p IMI: Ruled out for MI at OSH.
   - Continue ASA/Plavix. Unclear why patient is not on a BB or statin
   - Hold Ace/[**Last Name (un) 284**] in the setting of ARF
   .
   # Gout
   - Renally dose Allopurinol
   FEN: NPO, IVF, replete as necessary
   PPx: Heparin SQ, H2B, bowel regimen.
   Access:  RIJ CVL
   Code: FULL
   Communication: [**Name (NI) **] wife, [**Name (NI) 4551**] (RN) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6343**] - cell
   Disposition: ICU level of care for now

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and previous myocardial infarction (MI) who presented to the emergency department with high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status (AMS), and acute respiratory failure. He was transferred from an outside hospital for further management.

The patient's current condition includes sepsis, respiratory failure, acute kidney injury (ARF), ileus, and diabetes mellitus. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 600 mL, respiratory rate set at 18 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) at 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 60%. The patient is also receiving vasopressor support with levophed.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 13.9 K/uL, elevated creatinine levels ranging from 4.6 to 4.8 mg/dL, and elevated lactate levels at 0.8 mmol/L. The patient's blood cultures are positive for gram-positive cocci (GPCs).

The assessment and plan include the following:

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and previous myocardial infarction (MI) with stenting to the right coronary artery (RCA). The patient was transferred from another hospital for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status (AMS), and acute renal failure (ARF).

The patient has been diagnosed with sepsis due to gram-positive cocci (GPC) bacteremia. He is currently receiving invasive ventilation, multi-lumen catheter, and arterial line. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 73 beats per minute, blood pressure of 107/56 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, elevated blood glucose, and elevated creatinine level indicating renal dysfunction. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal range.

Assessment and Plan:
1. ID: The patient has high-grade bacteremia with GPCs and a foot ulcer as the potential source of infection. No other source has been identified, and endocarditis should also be considered. The patient will continue receiving vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam antibiotics.
2. Neuro: The patient's coma is multifactorial due to sepsis

   Mr. [**Known lastname 6349**] is a 55 yo male with DM 2, HTN, CAD s/p IMI and DES to
   RCAx3 transferred from OSH for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, AMS,
   and ARF.
   # ID: Patient with high grade bacteremia (4/4 bottles with GPCs) and
   report of wound culture with S.aureus with sensitivities unknown.
   Given that no other source identified, source may be diabetic foot
   ulcer/osteo. No CVL access in terms of line infections.  Would also
   need to consider endocarditis as source of infection.  Meningitis also
   considered given AMS, although LP deferred given difficulty with
   sedation.
   - Continue vancomycin, pip/tazo.
   - Low suspicion for meningitis, as patient was already hospitalized for
   4 days and a nosocomial meningitis is unlikely. Defer LP for now and
   hold CNS dosed ceftriaxone.
   - Surface echocardiogram today
   - Follow-up final foot plain film read
   - Trend WBC and fever
   - Consult podiatry
   # Neuro: CTH overnight negative for acute intracranial process. Likely
   multifactorial given high grade sepsis/bacteremia, ARF, and excessive
   narcotic use.
   - As above, continue vanco and pip/tazo
   - Defer LP and d/c ceftriaxone as suspicion for meningitis low
   - Follow-up neuron recs if any
   - serial neuron exams
   - Appreciate neuron recs, EEG today
   # ARF: Creatinine trending up to 4.8 from 1.3 at OSH. Differential
   includes contrast induced nephropathy, pre-renal, AIN in setting of
   antibiotic therapy, and ATN given sepsis.  FeNa 1.1 with negative urine
   eos. Patient continues to be oliguric/anuric with 4.5L IVF challenge
   overnight.
   - Renal U/S
   - Trend UOP and creatinine
   - Consider renal c/s
   # Respiratory Failure: Patient intubated given AMS and ?seizure for
   airway protection.
   - Daily RSBI and SBT if appropriate
   - Head of the bed elevated
   - H2 blocker while intubated
   - VAP bundle
   # Ileus: Demonstrated on OSH imaging. KUB wetread with distended
   transverse colon of 12 cm.  Most likely etiology is excessive narcotic
   use as patient was on high doses of MS Contin as an outpatient and
   continued to take narcotics at the OSH.
   - PO Naloxone
   - NGT to low-continuous suction
   - NPO
   - Hold narcotics
   - Upload OSH imaging and review with radiology.  If CTAP demonstrates
   transition point, consult surgery.
   # DM: Patient likely to have elevated FS while with infection.
   - Insulin gtt

Summary:
The patient's medical history includes diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and a previous myocardial infarction with subsequent stenting of the right coronary artery. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, and acute respiratory failure.

The patient is currently receiving invasive ventilation, multi-lumen access, arterial line, and prophylactic medications such as heparin sodium, famotidine, and insulin. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits, with a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 73 bpm, blood pressure of 107/56 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%.

The patient's laboratory results indicate leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 13.9 K/uL, elevated blood glucose level of 156 mg/dL, and elevated creatinine level of 4.8 mg/dL. Other laboratory values including hemoglobin, platelet count, liver function tests, and electrolyte levels are within normal ranges.

The patient's physical examination reveals a markedly distended and tympanic abdomen, bowel sounds not appreciated, and two stage 3 ulcers on the left foot without surrounding cellulitis. Neurological examination shows downgoing toes bilaterally.

The patient has been diagnosed with high-grade bacteremia caused by gram-positive cocci, likely Staphylococcus aureus, and

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and coronary artery disease who was admitted to the ICU for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, and acute renal failure. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He has a fever and elevated white blood cell count, indicating an ongoing infection. The patient is being treated with nafcillin for suspected methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) infection from the foot ulcer.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Sepsis: The patient has high-grade bacteremia, which increases the risk of sepsis. Close monitoring of vital signs and trends in WBC and fever curve is necessary.
2. Meningitis: Although the patient is already hospitalized, there is a low suspicion for meningitis. However, a lumbar puncture (LP) may be considered to rule out meningitis, especially since the patient has altered mental status.
3. Endocarditis: Given the presence of MSSA bacteremia and a history of intravenous drug use, endocarditis should be considered as a potential source of infection.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient has acute renal failure, which is likely due to sepsis-induced acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Renal function should be closely monitored, and further investigations such as renal ultrasound and urine

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and coronary artery disease who was transferred from another hospital for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, and acute renal failure. 

The patient has several medical complications that require attention. These include sepsis with organ dysfunction, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, hypotension, impaired skin integrity, hyperglycemia, and constipation. 

For sepsis, the patient is on nafcillin and Levophed. Pressors should be weaned off once the mean arterial pressure (MAP) is above 65, and the patient's urine output should be monitored with a goal of at least 30 cc/hr. 

In terms of identification of the source of infection, the patient has high-grade bacteremia with MSSA, and it is likely originating from a diabetic foot ulcer. No central line access has been identified as a source of infection. An echocardiogram showed normal valves, mild left ventricular hypertrophy, and an ejection fraction greater than 55%. 

Regarding the neurological assessment, a CT head scan was negative for acute intracranial processes. The altered mental status is likely multifactorial due to sepsis/bacteremia, acute renal failure, and excessive narcotic use. 

The patient's renal function is deteriorating with a creatinine level of 6.5 from 1.3 at the transferring hospital. The differential

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and previous myocardial infarction (MI) who was transferred from another hospital for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status (AMS), and acute renal failure (ARF). The patient is currently in the ICU and has several medical complications.

Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has high-grade bacteremia and a foot ulcer with methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). There is a need to consider endocarditis as a potential source of infection, and meningitis is also being considered due to AMS. However, a lumbar puncture (LP) has been deferred for now.
2. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated due to AMS and possible seizure for airway protection. His PaO2/FiO2 ratio is less than 200, but without classic bilateral infiltrates. There is uncertainty regarding the diagnosis of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have increased from 1.3 to 4.8, indicating worsening renal function. The differential diagnosis includes contrast-induced nephropathy, pre-renal azotemia, allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN), and acute tubular necrosis (ATN) secondary to sepsis. The patient

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 72-inch tall male with a weight of 180 lbs.
- The patient has a history of MSSA infection in the foot ulcer and osteoarthritis in the left first toe.
- The patient has undergone a CT scan and ultrasound, which showed dilated transverse colon dilation.
- The patient has acute renal failure likely due to sepsis.
- The patient's neurological status is concerning, and a lumbar puncture was strongly recommended but deferred for now.
- The patient is experiencing respiratory failure, constipation, impaired skin integrity, hypotension, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, hyperglycemia, and hyperkalemia.
- The patient has an arterial line and multi-lumen line inserted.
- The patient is receiving prophylactic antibiotics and stress ulcer medication.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration. Close monitoring and adjustment of ventilator settings are necessary.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and there is a risk of worsening kidney injury. Monitoring urine output, electrolyte imbalances, and adjusting fluid management is crucial.
3. Sepsis: The patient has severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, indicating a systemic infection. Continuous monitoring of vital signs, laboratory parameters, and source control are essential.
4. Impaired skin integrity: The patient has impaired skin

   RCAx3 transferred from OSH for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, AMS,
   and ARF.
   # Sepsis: In setting of high grade bacteremia.  Levophed off briefly ,
   but back on this AM.
   - Wean pressors, goal MAP>65

   - Trend WBC and fever curve
   # ID: Patient with high grade bacteremia (4/4 bottles with GPCs) and
   report of wound culture with MSSA.  Source is likely diabetic foot
   ulcer/osteo. No CVL access in terms of line infections.  Would also
   need to consider endocarditis as source of infection.  Meningitis also
   considered given AMS, although LP deferred given likely source of
   bacterimia.  Echo with normal valves. Mild LVH, EF > 55%.  Foot plain
   film read suspicious for osteo.
   - Continue nafcillin.
   - Low suspicion for meningitis, as patient was already hospitalized for
   4 days and a nosocomial meningitis is unlikely. Consider LP although
   has been on abx so unlikely to help r/o meningitis.
   - Trend WBC and fever. Consider TEE if bcx continue to be positive or

 for now they will defer
   amputation and await extubation of patient for surgery.
   # Neuro: CTH negative for acute intracranial process. Likely
   multifactorial given high grade sepsis/bacteremia, ARF, and excessive
   narcotic use.
   - Consider LP for ?SAH despite nl head ct
   - As above, transitioned to nafcillin for MSSA
   - d/c ceftriaxone as suspicion for meningitis low
   - Follow-up neuro recs if any

   # ARF: Creatinine trending up now to 6.5 from 1.3 at OSH. Differential
   includes contrast induced nephropathy, pre-renal, AIN in setting of
   antibiotic therapy, and ATN given sepsis and hypotension.  FeNa 1.1
   with negative urine eos. Patient continues to be oliguric/anuric with
   4.5L IVF challenge.  Renal U/S without hydronephrosis.
   - Trend UOP and creatinine

   status.

   airway protection.  P/F <200, although patient does not have classic
   bilateral infiltrates. He also has a history of CAD, and in setting of
   volume challenge may have element of heart failure, making ARDS
   clinical diagnosis unclear. If needs diuresis will require HD most
   likely as currently anuric in setting of ARF
   - Low volume ARDS settings for now.

   # Ileus: Demonstrated on OSH imaging. KUB wetread with distended

   use as patient was on high doses of MS Contin as anoutpatient and
   continued to take narcotics at the OSH.
   - PO Naloxone
   - OGT to low-intermitent suction
   - NPO

   - Upload OSH imaging and review with radiology.

   - Insulin SS
   .

   - Continue ASA/Plavix. Unclear why patient is not on a BB or statin

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and previous myocardial infarction. He was transferred to the ICU from another hospital for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, and acute renal failure. The patient's vital signs are stable, but he has ongoing sepsis with suspected MSSA infection from a diabetic foot ulcer. There is also concern for possible endocarditis, meningitis, and impaired skin integrity. The patient is intubated due to AMS and respiratory failure, with unclear distinction between ARDS and heart failure. He has acute kidney injury with worsening creatinine levels and anuria. Other issues include ileus, hyperglycemia, and a history of coronary artery disease.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has high-grade bacteremia and signs of sepsis. It is crucial to continue appropriate antibiotic therapy and closely monitor vital signs and laboratory values.
2. Diabetic Foot Ulcer: The source of MSSA infection is likely the patient's diabetic foot ulcer. Proper wound care and management are essential to prevent further complications.
3. Endocarditis: Considering the patient's history of CAD and the presence of bacteremia, endocarditis should be considered as a potential source of infection.
4. Meningitis: Although the likelihood of nosocomial meningitis is low, it should still be considered given the patient's

Summary:
Mr. [**Known Last Name 6349**], a 55-year-old male with diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and coronary artery disease (CAD) status post inferior myocardial infarction (IMI) and drug-eluting stent placement in the right coronary artery (RCA), was transferred from another hospital (OSH) for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status (AMS), and acute renal failure (ARF).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has a high-grade bacteremia and is showing signs of severe infection. Immediate management should include weaning off Levophed, maintaining a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 65, continuing nafcillin (since MSSA is likely from the foot ulcer), and monitoring the white blood cell (WBC) and fever curve.

2. Infectious Disease (ID): Considering the patient's high-grade bacteremia and report of wound culture with methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA), it is important to consider endocarditis as a potential source of infection. Additionally, meningitis should be considered given the AMS, although lumbar puncture (LP) is deferred due to the likely source of bacteremia. An echocardiogram with normal valves, mild left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH), and ejection fraction (EF) greater than 55% has been done. Foot plain film shows suspicious osteomyelitis. Continue nafcillin and trend WBC and fever. Consider transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) if blood cultures (bcx) continue to be positive or if fevers persist.

3. Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine is trending up to 7.8 from 1.3 at OSH, muddy brown casts are seen, and acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is suspected from sepsis and hypotension. FeNa is 1.1 with negative urine eos. The patient continues to be oliguric/anuric. Renal ultrasound without hydronephrosis has been done. Trend UOP and creatinine, obtain renal culture/sensitivity (c/s), and monitor urine output (UOP) to determine if hemodialysis (HD) for fluid overload is necessary.

4. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated due to AMS and possibly a seizure for airway protection. PaO2/FiO2 (P/F) ratio is less than 200, although the patient does not have classic bilateral infiltrates. He also has a history of CAD, and in the setting of volume challenge, may have an element of heart failure, making acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) diagnosis unclear. If UOP does not improve, diuresis may be required to improve respiratory status. Daily respiratory system bilirubin index (RSBI) and spontaneous breathing trial (SB

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and previous myocardial infarction. He was transferred from another hospital for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, and acute renal failure. The patient has multiple medical complications including sepsis, respiratory failure, renal failure, impaired skin integrity, hyperglycemia, and ileus. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has high-grade bacteremia and signs of infection. It is crucial to continue appropriate antibiotic therapy and monitor vital signs closely.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to sepsis and hypotension. Daily respiratory support and weaning of pressors should be considered.

3. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure with a rising creatinine level. Renal function should be closely monitored, and further diagnostic tests such as renal ultrasound and urine analysis should be performed.

4. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient has a foot ulcer that is likely the source of infection. Proper wound care and consultation with a podiatrist and vascular surgeon are recommended.

5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated. Insulin therapy should be adjusted to maintain glycemic control.

6. Ileus: The patient has demonstrated signs of ileus.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease (CAD), and recent intensive care unit (ICU) admission for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status (AMS), and acute renal failure (ARF). The patient underwent a lumbar puncture (LP) and angiography. He was made do not resuscitate (DNR) at a family meeting. The LP cell count was consistent with bacterial meningitis, and the patient was started on vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and acyclovir. Ampicillin was not started due to an untreated listeria infection for 5 days. The plan for transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) in the morning and MRI/MRV head ordered to rule out venous sinus thrombosis per neuro recommendations. The patient desaturated to 88% with decreased systolic blood pressure (SBP) in the 80s. He was suctioned, which improved oxygen saturation to 91%, but there were concerns about aspiration given the suctioning of increased bile-colored sputum. The patient coughed up bilious emesis during the LP and had a smaller episode during the day. Levophed was restarted at the lowest dose, and the patient's condition improved to 120s. Arterial blood gas (ABG) showed a pH of 7.33, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 44 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 68 mmHg. Recruitment maneuvers were attempted, and the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) was increased to 17 with worsening, so the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) was increased to 70% instead, which improved the patient's condition.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.4°C (99.3°F), heart rate (HR) of 80 beats per minute, SBP of 146/64 mmHg, respiratory rate (RR) of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 95%. The patient's height is 72 inches, and his central venous pressure (CVP) is 12 mmHg. The patient received fluids totaling 1,752 mL and had blood product transfusions totaling 423 mL. The patient's urine output was 223 mL, and he had nasogastric (NG) drainage of 200 mL. Laboratory results showed a white blood cell (WBC) count of 10.7 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hgb) of 9.2 g/dL, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 28.0 mg/dL, creatinine (Cr) of 7.8 mg/dL, sodium (Na+) of 137 mEq

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease (CAD), and previous myocardial infarction (MI) who was transferred from another hospital for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status (AMS), and acute renal failure (ARF). The patient underwent a lumbar puncture and angiography on April 24th.

Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has high-grade bacteremia and a foot ulcer suspected to be the source of infection. There is a possibility of endocarditis as well.
- Wean pressors and maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65.
- Continue nafcillin for methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) likely from the foot.
- Trend white blood cell (WBC) and fever curve.

2. Infectious Disease (ID): The patient's high-grade bacteremia and wound culture with MSSA suggest a diabetic foot ulcer as the source of infection. An echocardiogram showed normal valves, but there is mild left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) with an ejection fraction >55%. The foot plain film is suspicious for osteomyelitis. The lumbar puncture showed meningitis.
- Transitioned antibiotics to ceftriaxone, vancomycin (dosed by level), and acyclovir.
- Trend W

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and coronary artery disease who was transferred from an outside hospital for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, and acute renal failure. He underwent a lumbar puncture and angiography on the same day. The patient's family meeting was held to discuss his renal failure, meningitis, and do-not-resuscitate (DNR) status. He was started on vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and acyclovir due to the suspicion of bacterial meningitis. However, ampicillin was not started as the white blood cell count did not suggest untreated listeria infection.

The patient's condition has been fluctuating, with episodes of desaturation and hypotension requiring interventions such as recruitment maneuvers, increased FiO2, and levophed infusion. He also coughed up bilious emesis during the lumbar puncture and had episodes of aspiration.

Further diagnostic tests ordered include an arterial blood gas (ABG), transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), and magnetic resonance imaging/magnetic resonance venography (MRI/MRV) of the head to rule out venous sinus thrombosis. 

The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 37.4°C (99.3°F)
- Heart rate: 80 bpm (72-88)
- Blood pressure: 146/64 mm

   55 yo male with DM 2, HTN, CAD s/p IMI and DES to RCAx3 transferred
   from OSH for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, AMS, and ARF with
   meningitis on LP.
   # Sepsis: In setting of high grade bacteremia.  Levophed PRN.
   - goal MAP>60->will reassess pressure goals once MRI done as may change
   in setting of thrombosis
   - Continue CTX, Vanc (dosed by level), and acyclovir
   - f/u blood and CSF cxs
   - Trend WBC and fever curve
   - Because wbc lower than expected in CSF may be treated meningitis in
   which case cultures may be negative
   # ID: Patient with high grade bacteremia (4/4 bottles with GPCs) and
   report of wound culture with MSSA.  Source is likely diabetic foot
   ulcer/osteo. No Would also need to consider endocarditis as source of
   infection.    Echo with normal valves. Mild LVH, EF > 55%.  Foot plain
   film read suspicious for osteo.  LP showed menigitis
   - Transitioned Abx to CTX, Vanc (dosed by level), and Acyclovir
   - Trend WBC and fever.
   - TEE for ? endocarditis.
   - F/u  podiatry and vascular surgery recs
 for now they will defer
   amputation and await extubation of patient for surgery.
   # Neuro: CTH negative for acute intracranial process. LP had
   meningitis. EEG c/w alpha coma which correlates with poor-prognosis and
   concerning for higher-grade brain pathology or venous thrombosis
   - As above, transitioned to Abx to cover meningitis
   - MRI/V today to assess for venous thrombosis in setting of high grade
   meningitis
   - Follow-up neuro recs if any
   - Serial neuro exams
   - responding to pain still so Propofol continued
 follow TGs and
   lipase
   # ARF: Creatinine trending up now to 7.8  from 1.3 at OSH.  Muddy brown
   casts seen and ATN suspected from sepsis and hypotension.  FeNa 1.1
   with negative urine eos. Patient continues to be oliguric/anuric.
   Renal U/S without hydronephrosis.
   - Trend UOP and creatinine
   - Renal c/s
   - will need HD today or tomorrow unless MRI confirms poor prognosis and
   goc change
   # Respiratory Failure: Patient intubated given AMS for airway
   protection.  P/F <200, although patient does not have classic bilateral
   infiltrates. He also has a history of CAD, and in setting of volume
   challenge may have element of heart failure, making ARDS clinical
   diagnosis unclear. If UOP does not pick up, likely will require
   dialysis to improve respiratory status.
   - Daily RSBI and SBT if appropriate
   - Head of the bed elevated
   - H2 blocker while intubated
   - VAP bundle
   - Wean FiO2 as able
   # Ileus: Demonstrated on OSH imaging. KUB with improved colonic
   distention.  Most likely etiology is excessive narcotic use as patient
   was on high doses of MS Contin as an outpatient and continued to take
   narcotics at the OSH.
   - patient passed stool this morning
   - PO Naloxone
   - OGT to low-intermitent suction
   - f/u Gen [**Doctor First Name **] rec.
   # DM: Patient likely to have elevated FS while with infection.
   - Increased Insulin SS and baseline insulin with better control of FSBS
   last few checks
   .
   # CAD s/p IMI: Ruled out for MI at OSH.
   - Continue ASA/Plavix. Unclear why patient is not on a BB or statin
   - Hold Ace/[**Last Name (un) 284**] in the setting of ARF

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient underwent a lumbar puncture and angiography on [**2165-4-24**].
- A family meeting was held to discuss the patient's renal failure, meningitis, and DNR status.
- The patient's LP cell count indicated bacterial meningitis, so they were started on vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and acyclovir. However, ampicillin was not started due to an untreated Listeria infection for 5 days.
- A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is planned for the morning, along with an MRI/MRV head to rule out venous sinus thrombosis, as recommended by the neuro team.
- The patient has a history of a single loop of prominent air-filled bowel seen in the mid abdomen since [**2165-4-21**], although the marked dilation of the transverse colon seen at that time is no longer apparent.
- The patient was informed about his diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma and was planning on cryoablation.
- The patient desatted to 88% with decreased SBP in the 80s. They were suctioned, which improved their O2 saturation to 91%. There is a question of aspiration due to suctioning of increased bile-colored sputum. The patient was restarted on the lowest dose of levophed with improvement

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and previous myocardial infarction (MI) and stent placement in the right coronary artery (RCA). The patient was transferred from another hospital for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status (AMS), and acute renal failure (ARF).

The patient's current condition includes sepsis, meningitis, respiratory failure, ileus, diabetes mellitus, and a history of coronary artery disease post MI. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 17 and FiO2 of 70%. He is sedated and not fully awake.

Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 274 K/uL, elevated blood glucose of 199 mg/dL, elevated creatinine of 7.8 mg/dL, and elevated lactate level of 28.0%. Imaging shows a single loop of prominent air-filled bowel seen in the mid abdomen, which has not significantly changed since April 21st.

The patient's plan includes weaning off pressors, continuing nafcillin (assuming methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus infection), monitoring WBC and fever curve, and performing a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) for endocarditis. The patient's central line, arterial line, and urinary catheter should be removed

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and a previous myocardial infarction who was transferred from another hospital for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, acute respiratory failure, and renal failure with meningitis on lumbar puncture. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation.

The patient has multiple medical complications that need to be addressed:

1. Sepsis: The patient has high-grade bacteremia and is likely suffering from sepsis. Antibiotics have been started, but further monitoring of blood and cerebrospinal fluid cultures is necessary. The patient's white blood cell count in the CSF is lower than expected, which may indicate treated meningitis.

2. Infective endocarditis: The patient has a history of a diabetic foot ulcer and osteomyelitis, which are potential sources of infection. An echocardiogram has shown normal valves, but a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is planned to rule out endocarditis. The patient's foot plain film also shows suspicious findings for osteomyelitis.

3. ARF (acute renal failure): The patient's creatinine levels have significantly increased from 1.3 to 7.8, and muddy brown casts have been seen on urinalysis. This suggests acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to sepsis and hypotension.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and coronary artery disease (CAD). He was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital (OSH) for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status (AMS), and acute renal failure (ARF) with meningitis on lumbar puncture (LP).

The patient has several ongoing medical issues:

1. Sepsis: The patient has high-grade bacteremia and is being treated with Levophed (norepinephrine) as needed. The goal is to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60. Once the MRI is done, the pressure goals may change if there is evidence of thrombosis.

2. Infectious Disease (ID): The patient has high-grade bacteremia with gram-positive cocci (GPCs) in four out of four bottles. There is also a report of wound culture with methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). The source of infection is likely a diabetic foot ulcer or osteomyelitis. An echocardiogram (Echo) showed mild left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) and ejection fraction (EF) greater than 55%. The valves are normal, but there is suspicion for endocarditis. A transesophageal echo (TEE) will be done to further evaluate for endocarditis. Foot plain film shows suspicion for osteomyel

- The patient has been treated with antibiotics and antivirals, and has undergone several tests including transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and lumbar puncture (LP).
- The TEE ruled out endocarditis, while the MRI showed no evidence of venous sinus thrombosis or ischemic event. The LP confirmed bacterial meningitis.
- The patient's renal function has significantly deteriorated, with a creatinine level of 9.8 and oliguric/anuric status. ATN is suspected due to sepsis and hypotension.
- The patient's respiratory status is also compromised, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of less than 200. The cause of respiratory failure is unclear, with potential contributions from AMS, heart failure, or ARDS.
- The patient has a history of CAD and was recently admitted for an inferior myocardial infarction (IMI) and stent placement in the right coronary artery (RCA).
- Other medical conditions include diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and a foot ulcer.

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with multiple medical complications. The patient has been diagnosed with bacterial meningitis, acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, hypotension, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, impaired skin integrity, and hyperglycemia. 

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.3°C (97.3°F), heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure of 127/58 mmHg (with readings ranging from 101/45 to 145/76 mmHg), respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on endotracheal tube ventilation with a FiO2 of 50%. 

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine, lactate, and C-reactive protein levels. The patient's electrolytes are within normal range, but the glucose level is elevated. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) values indicate respiratory acidosis with compensation. 

The patient is currently on multiple medications including midazolam, fentanyl, heparin sodium, and antibiotics. The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR) and the disposition is in the ICU. 

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include worsening respiratory failure, progression of renal failure, development of additional infections, complications related to impaired skin integrity, and further deterioration of the cardiovascular

   55 yo male with DM 2, HTN, CAD s/p IMI and DES to RCAx3 transferred
   from OSH for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, AMS, and ARF with
   meningitis on LP.
   # Sepsis:  Patient with high grade bacteremia.  TEE [**2165-4-25**] ruled out
   endocarditis.
   - Levophed PRN.  goal MAP>60
   - Continue CTX, Vanc (dosed by level)
   - would favor d/c
ing acyclovir
   - f/u blood and CSF cxs
   - Trend WBC and fever curve
   - Because wbc lower than expected in CSF may be treated meningitis in
   which case cultures may be negative
   # ID: Patient with high grade bacteremia (4/4 bottles with GPCs) and
   report of wound culture with MSSA.  Source is likely diabetic foot
   ulcer/osteo. TEE ruled out endocarditis. Foot plain film read
   suspicious for osteo.  LP showed meningitis
   - Transitioned Abx to CTX, Vanc (dosed by level)
   - Would favor d/c
ing Acyclovir
   - Trend WBC and fever.
   - F/u  podiatry and vascular surgery recs
 for now they will defer
   amputation and await extubation of patient for surgery.
   # Neuro: MRI/MRV on [**2165-4-25**] was negative for venous sinus thrombosis or
   other intracranial process. LP had meningitis.
   - Continue Abx to cover meningitis
   - Follow-up neuro recs if any
   - Serial neuro exams
   - pain control with fentanyl/midaz
   # ARF: Creatinine trending up now to 9.8 from 1.3 at OSH.  Muddy brown
   casts seen and ATN suspected from sepsis and hypotension.  FeNa 1.1
   with negative urine eos. Patient continues to be oliguric/anuric.
   Renal U/S without hydronephrosis. Mild hyperkalemia to 5.5.
   - f/u Renal recs
   - will need HD today
   # Respiratory Failure: Patient intubated given AMS for airway
   protection.  P/F <200, although patient does not have classic bilateral
   infiltrates. He also has a history of CAD, and in setting of volume
   challenge may have element of heart failure, making ARDS clinical
   diagnosis unclear. [**Name2 (NI) **] require dialysis to improve respiratory status.
   - Daily RSBI and SBT if appropriate
   - Head of the bed elevated
   - H2 blocker while intubated
   - VAP bundle
   - Wean FiO2 as able
   # Ileus:  patient passed stool on [**2165-4-26**]
   - PO Naloxone
   - would try to avoid narcotics.
   # DM: Patient likely to have elevated FS with infection.
   - Increased Insulin SS and baseline insulin with better control of FSBS
   last few checks
   .
   # CAD s/p IMI: Ruled out for MI at OSH.
   - Continue ASA/Plavix. Unclear why patient is not on a BB or statin
   - Hold Ace/[**Last Name (un) 284**] in the setting of ARF

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and coronary artery disease who was transferred to the ICU for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, and acute renal failure with meningitis on lumbar puncture. The patient has multiple medical complications including sepsis with organ dysfunction, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, impaired skin integrity, hyperglycemia, and meningitis.

The assessment and plan include:
1. Meningitis, bacterial: Continue antibiotics to cover meningitis.
2. Constipation (obstipation, fos): Continue medication as prescribed.
3. Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS): Daily respiratory system assessment and spontaneous breathing trial if appropriate.
4. Renal failure, acute (acute renal failure, ARF): Initiate hemodialysis today, follow-up renal recommendations, and monitor electrolyte levels.
5. Hypotension (not shock): Maintain mean arterial pressure above 60 mmHg.
6. Sepsis, severe (with organ dysfunction): Continue CTX and Vanc antibiotics, follow-up blood and cerebrospinal fluid cultures, trend WBC and fever curve, and consider de-escalation of acyclovir if meningitis is confirmed.
7. Impaired skin integrity: Monitor for any signs of infection or breakdown.
8. Hyperglycemia: Improve glycemic control through increased insulin administration.
9. Cardiac

   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with DM 2, HTN, CAD s/p IMI and DES to RCAx3 transferred
   from OSH for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, AMS, and ARF with
   meningitis on LP.
   # ID:  Patient with high grade MSSA bacteremia and UTI; source thought
   to be diabetic foot ulcer given OSH report of MSSA wound culture and
   plain film here suspicious for osteo. Now also with meningitis, cx
   pending and staph coag+ sputum. TEE [**2165-4-25**] ruled out endocarditis. Has
   not been on levophed since [**4-24**]. Pt afebrile with mildly improved
   leukocytosis today.
   - Goal MAP>60; levophed prn
   - Continue Ctx, vanc (dosed by level); d/c acyclovir
   - Trend WBC and fever curve
   - F/u blood and CSF cx; because wbc lower than expected in CSF, may be
   treated meningitis in which case cx may be negative
   - F/u ID recs
   - F/u podiatry and vascular surgery recs; for now they will defer
   amputation and await extubation of patient for surgery.
   # Neuro: No evidence of venous sinus thrombosis or other intracranial
   process on MRI/MRV. LP c/w bacterial meningitis.
   - Cont Ctx and vanc as above; d/c acyclovir
   - Follow-up neuro recs if any
   - Serial neuro exams
   - Pain control with fentanyl/midaz
   # ARF: Creatinine trending up now to 9.8 from 1.3 at OSH.  Muddy brown
   casts seen and ATN suspected from sepsis and hypotension.  FeNa 1.1
   with negative urine eos. Patient continues to be oliguric/anuric.
   Renal U/S without hydronephrosis. Mild hyperkalemia to 5.5.
   - F/u Renal recs
   - Will need HD today
   # Respiratory Failure: Patient intubated given AMS for airway
   protection.  LLL infiltrate concerning for pneumonia. Sputum growing
   coag+ staph. Likely also pleural effusion (he has a history of CAD, and
   in setting of volume challenge may have element of heart failure) as
   10.5L + over LOS; expected to improve with dialysis.  .
   - Afebrile w/ decreasing WBC on vanc/ctx; f/u sensitivities. If
   worsens, consider broadening abx to cover aspiration or HAP
   - HD as above
   - Wean PEEP/FiO2 as able with daily RSBI and SBT if appropriate;
   sedation changed to fentanyl/versed due to hypertriglyceridemia on
   propofol
   - Head of the bed elevated, H2 blocker while intubated, VAP bundle
   # Ileus:  patient passed stool on [**2165-4-26**]
   - Start tube feeds as ileus resolved
   - PO Naloxone
   - Would try to avoid narcotics although on fentanyl/versed currently
   # DM: Patient likely to have elevated FS with infection.
   - Increased Insulin SS and baseline insulin with better control of FSBS
   last few checks
   # CAD s/p IMI: Ruled out for MI at OSH.
   - Continue ASA/Plavix. Unclear why patient is not on a BB or statin
   - Hold Ace/[**Last Name (un) 284**] in the setting of ARF
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Start tube feeds today
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2165-4-21**] 07:50 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2165-4-21**] 10:24 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)
   Disposition: ICU
Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and coronary artery disease who was transferred to the ICU for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, and acute renal failure with meningitis. The patient has been diagnosed with MSSA bacteremia, UTI, meningitis, and pneumonia. He has been treated with antibiotics and has undergone a transesophageal echocardiogram which ruled out endocarditis. The patient's creatinine level is significantly elevated, indicating acute renal failure, and muddy brown casts are seen, suggesting acute tubular necrosis. The patient's respiratory status is stable, but there are concerns about possible ventilator-associated pneumonia. The patient has been intubated due to altered mental status and airway protection. There are also concerns about ileus, hyperglycemia, and cardiovascular disease.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has a history of MSSA pneumonia, and there are concerns about possible VAP due to the prolonged use of mechanical ventilation.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine level and oliguric/anuric status suggest AKI, possibly due to sepsis, hypotension, and acute tubular necrosis.
3. Diabetic foot infection: The patient has a foot ulcer, which is a potential source of infection.
4. Meningitis:

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. He presented to the hospital with high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, and acute respiratory failure. He was transferred from another hospital for further management.

The patient's recent events include being placed on hemodialysis (HD), weaning of positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP), initiation of tube feeding, starting insulin gtt for hyperglycemia, and discontinuation of total parenteral nutrition (TPN) due to aspiration.

Vital signs show that the patient is afebrile with mildly improved leukocytosis. Blood cultures have been obtained, and the patient is receiving appropriate antibiotics for suspected methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia and urinary tract infection (UTI), as well as possible meningitis. The source of infection is believed to be a diabetic foot ulcer, confirmed by an MSSA wound culture from the previous hospital.

The patient's respiratory status is being closely monitored, and there are concerns about pneumonia and pleural effusion. He is currently receiving hemodialysis due to acute renal failure (ARF) with muddy brown casts and anuria. His creatinine level has improved from 9.8 to 8.0 mg/dL after the first HD session.

Other assessments and plans include management of diabetic ketoacidosis

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and coronary artery disease who was admitted to the ICU for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status (AMS), acute renal failure (ARF) with meningitis on lumbar puncture (LP). 

The patient has multiple medical complications that require close monitoring and management. Some potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Infection: The patient has high-grade MSSA bacteremia and a urinary tract infection (UTI) suspected to be from a diabetic foot ulcer. He also has meningitis, which needs to be treated promptly to prevent further complications.

Sputum culture is growing coag+ staph, indicating a possible respiratory infection. Pleural effusion is also suspected. Weaning off ventilator support will be considered based on daily respiratory system compliance and spontaneous breathing trials (SBT).

The patient has been in the ICU for several days, receiving multiple medications including antibiotics, sedatives, and pain management. The patient's vital signs are stable, but there are concerns about his respiratory status and fluid balance. The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count and creatinine levels, as well as abnormal liver function tests. There are potential medical complications related to the patient's prolonged stay in the ICU, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and stress ulcers. The patient's code status is full code.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been on mechanical ventilation for an extended period, which increases the risk of developing VAP. Close monitoring of respiratory symptoms and culture surveillance is necessary.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Prolonged immobility in the ICU increases the risk of developing blood clots in the deep veins. Regular lower extremity assessments and consideration of prophylactic anticoagulation therapy may be needed.
3. Stress ulcers: The patient's critical illness and prolonged ICU stay increase the risk of stress ulcers. Monitoring for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and providing appropriate prophylaxis are important.
4. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance shows a positive balance, indicating potential fluid overload.

   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with DM 2, HTN, CAD s/p IMI and DES to RCAx3 transferred
   from OSH for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, AMS, and ARF with
   meningitis on LP.
   # ID:  Patient with high grade MSSA bacteremia and UTI; source thought
   to be diabetic foot ulcer given OSH report of MSSA wound culture and
   plain film here suspicious for osteo. Now also with meningitis, cx
   pending and staph coag+ sputum. TEE [**2165-4-25**] ruled out endocarditis. Has
   not been on levophed since [**4-24**]. Pt afebrile with mildly improved
   leukocytosis today.
   - Goal MAP>60; levophed prn
   - Trend WBC and fever curve
   - F/u blood and CSF cx; because wbc lower than expected in CSF, may be
   treated meningitis in which case cx may be negative
   - Continue Ctx, vanc (dosed by level; f/u ID recs
   - F/u podiatry and vascular surgery recs; for now they will defer
   amputation and await extubation of patient for surgery.
   # Neuro: No evidence of venous sinus thrombosis or other intracranial
   process on MRI/MRV. LP c/w bacterial meningitis.
   - Cont Ctx and vanc as above for now
   - Serial neuro exams
   - Pain control with fentanyl/midaz
   - Neuro signed off
   # ARF: Creatinine trending up now to 9.8 from 1.3 at OSH.  Muddy brown
   casts seen and ATN suspected from sepsis and hypotension.  FeNa 1.1
   with negative urine eos. Patient continues to be oliguric/anuric.  S/p
   HD yesterday with improvement in Cr.
   - Plan for HD again today
   - F/u Renal recs
   # Respiratory Failure: Patient intubated given AMS for airway
   protection.  LLL infiltrate concerning for pneumonia. Sputum growing
   coag+ staph. Likely also pleural effusion (he has a history of CAD, and
   in setting of volume challenge may have element of heart failure);
   initiated dialysis yesterday and able to lower PEEP but still 10L+ over
   LOS.
   - Afebrile w/ decreasing WBC on vanc/ctx; f/u sensitivities. If
   worsens, consider broadening abx to cover aspiration or HAP
   - Cont HD and pull off volume as tolerated
   - Wean PEEP/FiO2 as able with daily RSBI and SBT if appropriate;
   sedation changed to fentanyl/versed due to hypertriglyceridemia on
   propofol
   - Head of the bed elevated, H2 blocker while intubated, VAP bundle
   # Ileus:  patient passed stool on [**2165-4-26**], restarted on tube feeds
   yesterday
   - KUB ordered but  ileus less likely as able to tolerate tube feeds
   when restarted
   - PO Naloxone
   - Would try to avoid narcotics although on fentanyl/versed currently
   # DM: Patient likely to have elevated FS with infection.
   - Increased Insulin SS and baseline insulin with better control of FSBS
   last few checks
   # CAD s/p IMI: Ruled out for MI at OSH.
   - Continue ASA/Plavix. Unclear why patient is not on a BB or statin
   - Hold Ace/[**Last Name (un) 284**] in the setting of ARF

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C (98.4°F), heart rate of 81 bpm (with a normal range of 70-99 bpm), blood pressure of 157/57 mmHg (with a normal range of 83/47-191/85 mmHg), respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute (with a normal range of 16-30 breaths per minute), and oxygen saturation of 97% on 50% FiO2.

   55 yo male with DM 2, HTN, CAD s/p IMI and DES to RCAx3 transferred
   from OSH for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, AMS, and ARF with
   meningitis on LP.
   # ID:  Patient with high grade MSSA bacteremia and UTI; source thought
   to be diabetic foot ulcer given OSH report of MSSA wound culture and
   plain film here suspicious for osteo. Now also with meningitis, cx
   pending and staph coag+ sputum. TEE [**2165-4-25**] ruled out endocarditis. Has
   not been on levophed since [**4-24**]. Pt febrile last PM, but hemodynamically
   stable.
   - Goal MAP>60; levophed prn
   - Trend WBC and fever curve
   - F/u blood and CSF cx; because wbc lower than expected in CSF, may be
   treated meningitis in which case cx may be negative
   - Continue Ctx, vanc (dosed by level).
   - F/u podiatry and vascular surgery recs; for now they will defer
   amputation and await extubation of patient for surgery.
   # HTN: started yesterday during dialysis.  Currently spikes up to
   210
s.  Etiologies include pain, essential htn, fever related.  Given
   withdrawal to pain on exam, this is most likely etiology.
   - treat pain with fentanyl boluses
   - start metoprolol [**Hospital1 **]
   - Esmolol for quick on/off
   - renal will UF at next HD.
   # Neuro: No evidence of venous sinus thrombosis or other intracranial
   process on MRI/MRV. LP c/w bacterial meningitis.
   - Cont Ctx and vanc as above for now
   - Serial neuro exams
   - Pain control with fentanyl/midaz
   - Neuro signed off
   # ARF: Initiated HD per renal.  Muddy brown casts seen and ATN
   suspected from sepsis and hypotension.  FeNa 1.1 with negative urine
   eos. Patient continues to be oliguric/anuric.  S/p HD yesterday with
   improvement in Cr.
   - No HD today
   - F/u Renal recs
   # Respiratory Failure: Patient intubated given AMS for airway
   protection.  LLL infiltrate concerning for pneumonia. Sputum growing
   MRSA. Likely also pleural effusion (he has a history of CAD, and in
   setting of volume challenge may have element of heart failure);
   initiated dialysis and able to lower PEEP but still 10L+ over LOS.
   - Continue vanc/ctx. If worsens, consider broadening abx to cover
   aspiration or HAP
   - Cont HD and pull off volume as tolerated
   - Wean PEEP/FiO2 as able with daily RSBI and SBT if appropriate;
   sedation changed to fentanyl/versed due to hypertriglyceridemia on
   propofol
   - Head of the bed elevated, H2 blocker while intubated, VAP bundle
   # Ileus:  patient passed stool, restarted on tube feeds
   - resolved with large BMs as of [**2165-4-26**]
   - monitor for constipation with pain control
   # DM: Patient likely to have elevated FS with infection.
   - Cte insulin gtt
   # CAD s/p IMI: Ruled out for MI at OSH.
   - Continue ASA/Plavix. Unclear why patient is not on a BB or statin
   - Hold Ace/[**Last Name (un) 284**] in the setting of ARF
   ICU Care

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease who presented with high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, acute respiratory failure, and meningitis. The patient's medical history includes a previous myocardial infarction and drug-eluting stent placement in the right coronary artery.

The patient has been diagnosed with multiple medical complications including bacterial meningitis, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, hypotension, sepsis, and impaired skin integrity. He also has hyperglycemia and a history of coronary artery disease.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:
- Administering antibiotics (vancomycin and ceftriaxone) for meningitis and bacteremia.
- Maintaining goal mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60, using levophed as needed.
- Trending white blood cell count and fever curve.
- Following up on blood and cerebrospinal fluid cultures.
- Continuing tube feeds and monitoring for constipation.
- Treating pain with fentanyl boluses.
- Starting metoprolol for hypertension.
- Providing pain control with fentanyl and midazolam.
- Initiating hemodialysis for acute renal failure.
- Weaning PEEP/FiO2 as able with daily respiratory system assessment and spontaneous breathing trial if appropriate.
- Elevating the head of the bed, using a H2 blocker while intubated, and

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a well-nourished male admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure. The patient has been on invasive ventilation since admission and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, pressure support of 8 cmH2O, and a PEEP of 8 cmH2O. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.44, PaCO2 of 43 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 200. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.2°C, heart rate of 81 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 124/46 to 196/71 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's neurological status is described as poor, with no withdrawal to pain. 

The patient has a history of bacterial meningitis, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, hypotension, sepsis with organ dysfunction, impaired skin integrity, and hyperglycemia. The patient's labs indicate leukocytosis with a WBC count of 12.2 K/uL, anemia with a Hct of 26.4%, thrombocytopenia with a Plt of 123 K/uL, elevated creatinine levels, and elevated lactate levels. The patient's electrolytes show hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypophosphatemia. 

The patient's nutrition is being provided through enteral feeding with Nutren Renal (Full) at a rate of 47 mL/hour. The patient has multiple lines including an arterial line, multi-lumen central venous catheter, and dialysis catheter. Prophylactic measures include DVT prophylaxis with boots and subcutaneous heparin, stress ulcer prophylaxis with an H2 blocker, and VAP prevention with head of bed elevation and oral care. The patient has a do not resuscitate (DNR) code status and is currently admitted to the ICU.

   55 yo male with DM 2, HTN, CAD s/p IMI and DES to RCAx3 transferred
   from OSH for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, AMS, and ARF with
   meningitis on LP.
   # ID:  Patient with high grade MSSA bacteremia and UTI; source thought
   to be diabetic foot ulcer given OSH report of MSSA wound culture and
   plain film here suspicious for osteo. Now also with meningitis, cx
   pending and staph coag+ sputum. TEE [**2165-4-25**] ruled out endocarditis. Has
   not been on levophed since [**4-24**]. Pt febrile last PM, but hemodynamically
   stable.
   - Goal MAP>60; levophed prn
   - Trend WBC and fever curve
   - F/u blood and CSF cx; because wbc lower than expected in CSF, may be
   treated meningitis in which case cx may be negative
   - Continue Ctx, vanc (dosed by level).
   - F/u podiatry and vascular surgery recs; for now they will defer
   amputation and await extubation of patient for surgery.
   # Neuro: No evidence of venous sinus thrombosis or other intracranial
   process on MRI/MRV. LP c/w bacterial meningitis.
   - Cont Ctx and vanc as above for now
   - Serial neuro exams
   - Pain control with fentanyl/midaz
   - Neuro signed off
   # ARF: Initiated HD per renal.  Muddy brown casts seen and ATN
   suspected from sepsis and hypotension.  FeNa 1.1 with negative urine
   eos. Patient continues to be oliguric/anuric.  S/p HD yesterday with
   improvement in Cr.
   - F/u Renal recs
   # Respiratory Failure: Patient intubated given AMS for airway
   protection.  LLL infiltrate concerning for pneumonia. Sputum growing
   MRSA. Likely also pleural effusion (he has a history of CAD, and in
   setting of volume challenge may have element of heart failure);
   initiated dialysis and able to lower PEEP but still 10L+ over LOS.
   - Continue vanc/ctx. If worsens, consider broadening abx to cover
   aspiration or HAP
   - Cont HD and pull off volume as tolerated
   - Wean PEEP/FiO2 as able with daily RSBI and SBT if appropriate;
   sedation changed to fentanyl/versed due to hypertriglyceridemia on
   propofol
   - Head of the bed elevated, H2 blocker while intubated, VAP bundle
   # Ileus:  patient passed stool on [**2165-4-26**], restarted on tube feeds
   yesterday
   - KUB ordered but  ileus less likely as able to tolerate tube feeds
   when restarted
   - PO Naloxone
   - Would try to avoid narcotics although on fentanyl/versed currently
   # DM: Patient likely to have elevated FS with infection.
   - Cte insulin gtt
   # CAD s/p IMI: Ruled out for MI at OSH.
   - Continue ASA/Plavix. Unclear why patient is not on a BB or statin
   - Hold Ace/[**Last Name (un) 284**] in the setting of ARF

He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status (AMS), acute renal failure (ARF), and meningitis.

The patient has multiple medical complications that require attention:

1. Meningitis: The patient has bacterial meningitis, as evidenced by the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis. He is being treated with antibiotics, but further follow-up is needed to monitor his response.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is on invasive ventilation due to acute respiratory failure. There is concern for pneumonia, and the sputum culture is positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The goal is to wean off the ventilator gradually while ensuring adequate oxygenation and respiratory support.

3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)/Renal Failure: The patient has AKI, likely secondary to sepsis and hypotension. He is oliguric/anuric and receiving hemodialysis (HD). The target is to improve renal function and reduce serum creatinine levels.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of shortness of breath and cough. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.2°C (100.8°F), heart rate of 82 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 177/62 mmHg to 201/80 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is receiving multiple medications including insulin, fentanyl, esmolol, midazolam, hydralazine, metoprolol, and heparin sodium.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, normal platelet count, elevated creatinine, and normal electrolyte levels. The patient's blood cultures were obtained on 04/28/2165 at 01:16 PM.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Meningitis: The patient has been diagnosed with bacterial meningitis, which is an infection of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. This condition can lead to complications such as increased intracranial pressure, seizures, and organ dysfunction.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing acute respiratory failure, which may be due to severe pneumonia or another underlying respiratory condition. This can result in inadequate oxygenation and ventilation, leading to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.

3. Renal Failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels indicate acute renal failure, which can be caused by severe infection, hypotension, or direct kidney injury. Renal failure may lead to fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and the need for dialysis.

4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is consistently elevated, indicating hypertension. If left uncontrolled, hypertension can cause end-organ damage, such as heart failure, stroke, or kidney disease.

5. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and symptoms of systemic infection suggest the possibility of sepsis. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that arises when the body's response to infection becomes dysregulated, leading to widespread inflammation and organ dysfunction.

6. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient has impaired skin integrity, possibly due to immobility or pressure ulcers. This can increase the risk of infection and compromised wound healing.

7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's elevated blood glucose levels indicate hyperglycemia, which can be caused by stress, infection, or inadequate insulin therapy. Hyperglycemia can lead to complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis or increased risk of infection.

These potential medical complications highlight the need for careful monitoring and management of the patient's condition in the ICU.

   55 yo male with DM 2, HTN, CAD s/p IMI and DES to RCAx3 transferred
   from OSH for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, AMS, and ARF with
   meningitis on LP.
   # ID:  Patient with high grade MSSA bacteremia and UTI; source thought
   to be diabetic foot ulcer given OSH report of MSSA wound culture and
   plain film here suspicious for osteo. Now also with meningitis. TEE
   [**2165-4-25**] ruled out endocarditis. Patient off pressors and hypertensive.
   Pt febrile last PM, but hemodynamically stable.
   - Trend WBC and fever curve
   - F/u blood and CSF cx; because wbc lower than expected in CSF, may be
   treated meningitis in which case cx may be negative
   - Continue Ctx, vanc (dosed by level).
   # HTN: started [**2165-4-27**] during dialysis.  Currently spikes up to 210
   Etiologies include pain, essential htn, fever related.  Given
   withdrawal to pain on exam, this is most likely etiology.
   - treat pain with fentanyl, but try not to over-sedate
   - increase metoprolol [**Hospital1 **]
   - Esmolol as needed for quick on/off
   - renal will UF at next HD.
   # Respiratory Failure: Patient intubated given AMS for airway
   protection.  LLL infiltrate concerning for pneumonia. Sputum growing
   MRSA. Patient vent requirements are minimal despite altered mental
   status.
   - Continue vanc/ctx. If worsens, consider broadening abx to cover
   aspiration or HAP
   - Cont HD and pull off volume as tolerated
   - Place NG tube for meds and nutrition
   - if still AMS but low vent need, will extubated and feed/meds via NG
   # Neuro: No evidence of venous sinus thrombosis or other intracranial
   process on MRI/MRV. LP c/w bacterial meningitis.
   - Cont Ctx and vanc as above for now
   - Wean sedation as tolerated by pain
   - Neuro signed off
   # ARF: Initiated HD per renal.  Muddy brown casts seen and ATN
   suspected from sepsis and hypotension.
   - UF today
   - F/u Renal recs
   # Ileus:  patient passed stool, restarted on tube feeds
   - resolved with large BMs as of [**2165-4-26**]
   - monitor for constipation with pain control
   # DM: Patient likely to have elevated FS with infection.
   - Cte insulin gtt
   - transition to Sub-Q heparin
   # L foot ulcer
   - F/u podiatry and vascular surgery recs; for now they will defer
   amputation and await extubation of patient for surgery.
   # CAD s/p IMI: Ruled out for MI at OSH.
   - Continue ASA/Plavix.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and coronary artery disease who presented with high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status (AMS), and acute renal failure (ARF). The patient was transferred from another hospital for meningitis on lumbar puncture (LP).

The patient has multiple medical complications, including bacterial meningitis, acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), acute renal failure, benign hypertension, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, impaired skin integrity, and hyperglycemia.

The assessment and plan include treating the patient's infections with appropriate antibiotics, managing hypertension with medication and renal ultrafiltration, providing respiratory support through mechanical ventilation, and treating acute renal failure with dialysis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening of respiratory failure due to pneumonia or aspiration, further deterioration of renal function leading to end-stage renal disease, development of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism due to immobilization, and complications related to diabetes mellitus such as elevated blood glucose levels or diabetic ketoacidosis.

It is important to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory values, and clinical condition to promptly address any potential complications and provide appropriate medical interventions.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and coronary artery disease who was transferred to the ICU for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, and acute renal failure with meningitis on lumbar puncture. The patient has a history of myocardial infarction and stent placement in the right coronary artery. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been diagnosed with bacterial meningitis, acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), acute renal failure, benign hypertension, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, and impaired skin integrity. The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Meningitis: The patient has been diagnosed with bacterial meningitis, which is a serious infection of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. It can lead to complications such as brain abscesses, hydrocephalus, hearing loss, vision loss, seizures, and neurological deficits.

2. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation due to acute respiratory failure. This condition can lead to further lung infections, atelectasis, and complications related to prolonged intubation such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and vocal cord edema.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which can progress to chronic kidney disease if not properly managed. Complications may include fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and uremic symptoms.

4. Hypert

   55 yo male with DM 2, HTN, CAD s/p IMI and DES to RCAx3 transferred
   from OSH for high-grade bacteremia, foot ulcer, AMS, and ARF with
   meningitis on LP.
   # ID:  Patient with high grade MSSA bacteremia and UTI; source thought
   to be diabetic foot ulcer given OSH report of MSSA wound culture and
   plain film here suspicious for osteo. Now also with LP suggestive of
   bacterial meningitis with neg cx to date; as WBC lower than expected in
   CSF, may be treated meningitis in which case cx may be negative. TEE
   [**2165-4-25**] ruled out endocarditis. Has been febrile with increased WBC but
   hemodynamically stable; off pressors and hypertensive.
   - Trend WBC and fever curve
   - F/u blood and CSF cx; check C. diff
   - Continue Ctx, vanc (dosed by level); ID to see this AM re:
   possibility of cefepime and vanco with HD to avoid PICC placement
   # HTN: Started [**2165-4-27**] during dialysis. Etiologies include pain,
   essential htn, fever related.  Better ctrl with pain ctrl and on
   standing beta blocker; now off gtt.
   - Off fentanyl gtt and on home fentanyl patch
   - Cont metoprolol 50mg pot id; uptitrate prn
   - 3L ultrafiltrated at HD yesterday
   # Respiratory Failure: Patient intubated given AMS for airway
   protection.  LLL infiltrate concerning for pneumonia. Sputum growing
   MRSA. Patient vent requirements are minimal despite altered mental
   status.
   - Continue Vanc/ctx. If worsens, consider broadening abx to cover
   aspiration or HAP
   - Cont HD and pull off volume as tolerated
   - Place NG tube for meds and nutrition
   - Plan to extubate today pending clarification of DNI status
   # Neuro: No evidence of venous sinus thrombosis or other intracranial
   process on MRI/MRV. LP c/w bacterial meningitis. New head twitching
   yesterday with no evidence of change on CT heda
   - Cont Ctx and vanc as above for now; f/u ID recs
   - Wean sedation as tolerated by pain
   - Neuro signed off
   # ARF: Initiated HD per renal.  Muddy brown casts seen and ATN
   suspected from sepsis and hypotension.
   - F/u Renal recs; if no improvement in next 1-2 days, remove femoral
   line and place IJ
   # Ileus:  patient passed stool, restarted on tube feeds
   - resolved with large BMs as of [**2165-4-26**]
   - monitor for constipation with pain control
   # DM: Patient likely to have elevated FS with infection; now off
   insulin gtt
   - Cont NPH [**Hospital1 **] with ISS
   # L foot ulcer
   - F/u podiatry and vascular surgery recs; for now they will defer
   amputation and await extubation of patient for surgery.
   # CAD s/p IMI: Ruled out for MI at OSH.
   - Continue ASA/Plavix.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Confirm NGT placement then resume tube feeds if AMS limits
   ability to take po
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2165-4-21**] 07:50 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2165-4-21**] 10:24 PM
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2165-4-26**] 08:20 AM

   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate) ; clarify if DNI prior to
   extubation
   Disposition:ICU

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and coronary artery disease who was admitted to the ICU for high-grade MSSA bacteremia, foot ulcer, altered mental status, and acute respiratory failure. The patient also had meningitis on lumbar puncture, but no evidence of acute intracranial pathology on CT head. The patient's condition has been complicated by respiratory failure, neurologic issues, acute renal failure, ileus, diabetes management, and a foot ulcer.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's high-grade MSSA bacteremia and UTI could lead to sepsis, especially considering the presence of a foot ulcer, which may serve as a source of infection. Monitoring vital signs and trends in laboratory values will help identify any signs of systemic infection.
2. Bacterial Meningitis: The patient's LP suggestive of bacterial meningitis should be closely monitored. Even though the CSF culture is negative so far, the possibility of treated meningitis cannot be ruled out. Repeat blood and CSF cultures should be done to ensure appropriate management.
3. Pneumonia: The LLL infiltrate raises concern for pneumonia. The patient's sputum is growing MRSA, which may require broadening antibiotic coverage. Close monitoring of respiratory status and follow-up chest x-rays will aid in managing this condition.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The muddy brown casts seen on
